content:
If your backup includes a copy of the profile folder, you can recover the address books and local folders mail. The profile default location is, e.g.:

C:\Users\username\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\xxxxxx.default-release

If you don't have a profile backup, it's possible to collect email addresses from whatever mail folders you have, with an add-on.

creator: cs999

content:
We tried a manual about 10 years ago. (I just looked it up to get the link and it was closer to 15, how time flies) No one read it so it basically lapsed into history, along with the user manuals for just about every other software product on the planet. There is a copy, here but it is very very dated https://archive.flossmanuals.net/thunderbird/

Really this forum is a great way to have someone do the searching for you if you can't find what you want. I certainly would not be paying for an online manual that is a copy of the free one I linked to that is almost 15 years out of date.

I would be very leery of any "manual" written more than 90 days ago really as version 128, released in recent weeks, rewrites a lot of things and last years version 115 reinvented a whole lot of wheels. Anything prior to that can really only be considered a pointer.

Fundamentally email is a relatively complex topic which for most folk "just works" (It is usually not the software than the book of instructions is required for). It is a more than passing understanding of the IMAP and POP mail protocols and forthcoming will be the Microsoft Exchange proprietary protocol and the highly reliant and basically broken technology used to "scan" incoming mail by "security" software that generates most of the support noise.

Finding someone in industry that actually understand mail, rather than Microsoft Exchange and Microsoft Outlook is often something of a challenge. Microsoft embarked on a very successful "in education" product placement, including steep discounts, a generation ago. Now we are seeing graduates that only know Microsoft, have never used a non Microsoft product for business office suite use and have little understanding of the the underlying technologies.

Mail on the whole is not difficult, because it is about matching connection parameters set by the mail provider with those on your machine and after that it "just works". Until your antivirus kills it, or someone at Thunderbird changes a default that you have no idea is a "thing" (and a manual will not really help there as most folk just accept defaults so they are not really documented.)

Primarily, most issues come from outside Thunderbird and through Thunderbird profile per install. which at times looses a profile and it has to be forcibly restated or rebuilt.

See these profile documents. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/dedicated-profile-thunderbird-installation https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data

Message threading. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/message-threading-thunderbird# Note the default is for new folders but due to bugs repair was loosing per folder settings like threading.

Inability to receive message generally comes here https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/cannot-receive-messages
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Well, that was an education, and thank you! So I'll have to learn to use the knowledge base. I really appreciate the time you devoted to that explanation. Maybe I can learn enough to be a help to someone else someday. One thing's for sure: I'm going to have to expand my vocabulary. Thunderbird forever!
creator: martypa

content: Most issues post upodate are caused by third party security tools (antivirus and firewall) See https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/cannot-receive-messages#w_is-your-account-configured-correctly

content: Did the update leave you with a request to define an email address? If so, your profile is probably still available and components can probably be recovered. You can check this with a few steps: - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder' - you are now in the profile in windows file explorer, click the back arrow to back up one folder - you are now in the ...appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profile folder, there may be more than one folder there, - look for abook.sqlite in each and last updated date. The one that is larger and older would be your addressbook. - if you have a POP account, look in the Mail folder for the account and message folders, such as inbox, inbox.msf. Those would be your message folders. TO activate the addressbook in thunderbird, click tools>import>importfromafile>importaddressbook>sqlitedatabasefile and then locate and select the discovered abook.sqlite. For the message files, a simple way is to - create local folder for each folder to retrieve - install the addon importeporttools if not already done - highlight new folder, rightclick and select the importexport option to import mbox and select one of the discovered message files (ignore the .msf files). - repeat above step for each messagefile.
creator: davidsk

content:
Note that Thunderbird 128 is shipping with a bug causing IMAP folder corruption under some circumstances. https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1890230

Some Thunderbird users report that they need to repair they IMAP mailboxes multiple times per week. https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1911067#c4

Another possibility, did you create an exception in your anti-virus software for the Thunderbird profile folder, so that the anti-virus real-time scanner will not scan it? https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_how-to-find-your-profile

Letting anti-virus scan a profile with large folders (80GB?) is asking for trouble. Anti-virus software is known to corrupt Thunderbird mail folders, and in the worst case can cause data loss. So make sure you do have a good backup of your Thunderbird profile. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_backing-up-a-profile

content: Zo werkt IMAP inderdaad; de wijziging wordt vanuit de Thunderbird-installatie bij afsluiten gesynchroniseerd met de server, waarna bij openen van de andere installatie deze weer vanaf de server wordt gesynchroniseerd. Het gebeurt helaas niet in realtime, dus échte synchronisatie is het niet.

content: the simplest way is to copy everything, not just an account or two. My approach works well for most: - exit thunderbird - copy thunderbird profile folder from c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming to external media - have thunderbird already installed on new PC and NOT running - copy the thunderbird folder on external media to c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming on new PC. This will overwrite the existing folder so approve when prompted - start thunderbird

creator: davidsk

content: Ok, I tend to be down and dirty sometimes, but this works for me. - first, go to profile at c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird and open profiles.ini. this is a simple text file, do NOT change it. it will give you the name of your profile folder. -now click the profiles folder under thunderbird folder and locate your profile. - open profile and COPY the prefs.js file somewhere else for safety - now, open prefs.js with a text editor such as notepad - do a search for the account - the first hit is probably on a line with identity.id with a number such as identity.id1. - highlight all the rows with that identity code and delete - continue search and another hit will be on a line wit server.serverx such as server.server3 - highlight and delete all rows with that server number - save and exit - now, if account was imap, open the imapmail folder and delete that account. If POP, look in the Mail folder - now restart thunderbird and it should be okay.

content: Hello @christ1, thanks for reply. So what is alternative then for IMAP? I try to achive, to prevent data lost, and to save my emails, in thunderbird, then to delete from gmail website. Because I lost an email address in the past, I don't want to repeat the unpleasant experience with gmail again. So I want all emails to be saved independently of gmail in Thunderbird, and then to delete them from gmail, but to remain only in Thunderbird and not to be deleted from Thunderbird. creator: beute.feinte

content:
You'd have to use POP instead of IMAP. Then you'd also have to manually replicate any folder hierarchy locally you may have on the IMAP server.

Alternatively you can move messages manually off of the server to your Local Folders account, and use it for archiving purposes. Same thing as for POP, you'd have to manually create the folder hierarchy you want.

Or take a look at an email archiving software like MailStore. https://www.mailstore.com/en/products/mailstore-home/
creator: christ1

content: Try with STARTTLS security on 587, normal password, and disable antivirus scanning by e.g. adding TB profile folder as an exception or exclusion.
